utterances: Reuben is almost too big for the MRI, but they got him in (laughter).
It's a big boy.
But the images show knots on his spine.
Dr. Jurney orders immediate surgery.
Going to take a peek at that last scan, and then we'll move our big boy out and then start the process of his very unattractive surgical haircut and go from there.
She has to slice through Reuben's leathery flesh and muscle.
So this is the drill that we will use to take off the bone on Reuben's spine so we can see his spinal cord and what's pressing on it.
(SOUNDBITE OF DRILL DRILLING)
Through a mist of bone and blood, Dr. Jurney sees small bits in Reuben's spine that have hardened around his nerves.
That's what we had to get out.
So his spinal cord's only about that big.
So something that big actually compresses it quite a good deal.
So...
And that's like desiccated parts of his spine.
Yeah, so it's the middle.
And it's supposed to be squishy.
And it is not squishy anymore.
So we'll see if we can get any more pieces out like that.
But that makes me feel better about Reuben.
The surgery takes more than an hour - lots of blood, bone and hot, bright lights.
But Carrie Jurney smiles as she slips down her surgical mask to phone the couple she calls Reuben's dads.
Hi, it's Dr. Jurney calling.
We're all done.
Your baby's waking up.
They were chronic discs, so those have been there for a while...
A long day in which we'd glimpse some of the stressors that can figure into suicides among veterinarians had ended with a triumph.
...So we made things way, way better than when we started.
So I think we did what we needed to do tonight.
A gifted team of nurses and surgeons had helped a big, beloved dog walk again and brought joy to the couple who loved him.
Dr. Jurney could go home happy.
All right, my friend, well, I am going to get your baby tucked in.
And then I will call you in the morning, OK?
Talk to you then.
OK, bye-bye.
All righty.
But a few days after Reuben's surgery, I got this message from Dr. Carrie Jurney.
Hey, Scott.
I thought I should let you know we lost Reuben today.
I have to be honest; this is gut-wrenching.
You came to us to see why the job is hard, and there is no better example than this.
I am devastated.
I've cried because my mind is with Reuben and his poor owners.
Even though I know I did everything I could for him, I still wonder if I could have done more.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And if you are troubled by thoughts of suicide, there is help.
The number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline is 1-800-273-8255.
You're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR New.
Also in St. Paul, Slate.com's chief political correspondent John Dickerson.
John, welcome back to the show.
Obviously, not the convention the GOP was hoping for and planning for.
So what is the message of the party and of Senator McCain with Hurricane Gustav?
You know, the message of this campaign was putting country first.
That was always the larger theme, and now Senator McCain gets to sort of put that in action.
He's turned the GOP fundraisers who are here - who raise money for the party, now they're going to raise money for Gustav victims.
The McCain website has turned into this place where people can go to not only give money, but where they can learn about Senator McCain's view that you know, one should always put country first.
He's talked since his 2000 campaign about serving a cause greater than self-interest.
So, he's trying to morph the campaign into a seminar on national service, which is both good policy in their view, but also good politics.
What about the response of the candidate himself?
He visited an emergency management facility in Mississippi yesterday and he's talking about - this is a non-political event.
Sure, that's what you're supposed to say.
Three years ago of course, President Bush mishandled badly the response to Hurricane Katrina.
That's obviously in every Republican's mind.
Senator McCain was also photographed when Katrina was hitting, with then-President Bush, with a birthday cake.
That's a bad image for Senator McCain.
Yeah.
Not only this last-minute drama typical.
It's - I think it's de rigueur.

But it's also true that this same drama plays out at the climate talks Europe, always has a mature aggressive stance than the United States does, and Europe always finds a way to make a big point over that in the talks and ends up looking greener by highlighting its less-ambitious United States position.
So this happens, yeah.
So, for you, in Bali, it's already Friday morning.
It means the last day of the meeting has begun already.
What are you expecting the outcome will be?

Well, it's always dangerous to predict outcomes of things, but I'll say that environmental groups are quite happy with the text that's floating around right now that's been negotiated and debated over night.
And if it had survived the night, which we'll find out a little while, it does contain the key provisions that form a good solid roadmap for a future treaty.
It has a mechanism to help the most vulnerable nations, it talks about technology and financing, and at least room to negotiate these targets even if they aren't mentioned in these texts right now.
Okay.
Thank you, Richard.
My pleasure.
That's NPR's Richard Harris at the climate change talks in Indonesia.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
(Soundbite of protests)

In Pakistan today, thousands of people took to the streets of the capital, Islamabad, demanding the reinstatement of the country's suspended chief justice and calling on Pakistan's military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, to step down.
The judge himself led the demonstrators through the streets en route to a seminar.
Scenes like these have become familiar to the beleaguered Musharraf.
NPR's Philip Reeves was among the crowd today and he found that the judge has brought some unusual new recruits to his cause.
(Soundbite of protests)
Anwa Afridi served in Pakistan's army for 28 years.
He's a retired colonel.
He fought against India, was wounded and collected a pile of medals, eight in all.
The other day, he took a momentous step.
I wrote a letter to the chief of Army staff that I do not want these medals, which I've earned with my blood.
I'm sending all these medals to you.
Afridi handed back his medals.
He says he also returned the free plot of land the government had given him and declared he'll no longer accept his military pension.
It's his way of protesting against the military rule of General Pervez Musharraf and, particularly, Musharraf's attempts to get rid of Pakistan's chief justice.
To rule the country is the job of the civilians.
To rule the country (unintelligible) the democratically elected people, not the man in uniform.

Most of those who've taken to the streets around the country in support of Pakistan's Chief Justice Iftikhar Chaudhry in the last few months are either lawyers or activists with opposition political parties.
The foundation of Musharraf's powerbase is the army of which Musharraf is the chief of staff.
Yet today, Afridi was marching through Islamabad with several thousand others, escorting the judge to a seminar held in the Supreme Court about the importance of an independent judiciary.
It was the colonel's first-ever demonstration.
After a while, it becomes clear that one reason he came was because of what happened in Karachi two weeks ago.
Forty-eight people died in gun battles, which Musharraf's opponents say were deliberately whipped up by a pro-government party.
When Afridi talks about this, he dissolves into tears.
My people, oh, poor Punjabis.
They kill everybody and innocent people.
The colonel is not the only unlikely figure in the crowd.
Fauzia Kasuri is a relative by marriage of Pakistan's foreign minister.
I'm only here in my capacity as a private citizen of Pakistan, a concerned citizen of Pakistan.
And I'm here to show support for the chief justice because I really think that what Pakistan is facing right now is the gravest crisis that we've ever had.
We've had a turbulent history in our pursuit for democracy.
And this is a very decisive and defining moment for our country.
It's a moment, some commentators believe, might just lead to the end of Musharraf's rule.
Such an outcome won't much trouble student Zahid Sadazahud(ph), another person out from the street in support of the judge for the first time.
For him, Musharraf simply isn't the answer to Pakistan's key problems, but Islam extremism.
It's not (unintelligible) by a general, who is cut off from reality, who is just sitting with the 16 guys and thinking the whole world is his.
You cannot simply do that.
If you don't include people into a system and if they don't have stakes in it, how can they get out of the vicious circle that they are in?
Philip Reeves, NPR News, Islamabad.
Summer weather has left people in the dark and sweltering in two major U.S.
cities.
A blackout in New York's borough of Queens has left up to 20,000 customers without power for six days now.
A series of Con Edison circuits failed after the state set a record for electricity use during a heat wave.
In St. Louis, the weather is cooler now, but hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses still have no power after a series of summer thunderstorms.
The first brought down power lines Wednesday.
Residents hope for quick relief but power company Ameren UE says it could be days before everyone is back online.
